Just read all about this place, Svalbard in an historically accurate bit of fiction. E.g. factual - real places, real characteristics of the place, geography, weather, conditions, danger, wildlife, reasons people even bother to go there, etc.) all real except for the characters and their deeds, though wholly within the realm of plausible.

This place is VERY inhospitable to humans. Polar bears are much more comfortable. Now the Russians and Chinese are spending inordinate amounts of time there with the Chinese trying to find the best location for a Air, Sea base in order to take over the new shipping lanes expected to open over the next 10 to 50 years with melting ice, such that ice breakers and commercial and merchant vessels able to navigate the routes. I've read that the Chinese are keen to exploit the resources of the arctic ocean and, of course, will very likely over fish the natural wealth of sea life in the region, as soon as they can get their giant commercial fishing vessels into the region. China is, as usual, making ridiculous claims of sovereignty over nearby land masses in order to 'justify' their presence and to claim ownership.

So, the US and NATO better get serious about maintaining our own presence in order to preserve freedom of navigation and to prevent the chinese and others from depleting, nay wasting, the natural resources present there.

Lots of folks are attacked by Polar Bears out there and at times the only to prevent being eaten is to shoot them, as it turns out that bear spray is too ineffectual with these predators. Polar bears are truly beautiful, but they stalk incredibly effectively and noises, of all kinds, will simply not scare them off the scent. Unlike all other bears, only Polar Bears will routinely see humans as a source of food, naturally. All other bears will either avoid humans entirely or, like the Alaskan Brown Bears (bigger than the Grizzley) will share the resources provided one maintains a very respectful distance from them.

Anyway, too cold for anything there except Polar Bears and seals and artic fox and certain rodents. Svalbard's weather routinely sees massive storms with winds of hurricane strength, together with temperature extremes. Climate change does not mean man-made global warming. The climate on earth has always been cyclical. Volcano eruptions release so-called greenhouse gasses in volume that is many, many times the amount of the same gasses that human behavior is capable of releasing.

What an experience it would be to live, work and go to school here. I'm not sure I could handle, breathing air this fresh and clean. Because when you come from a large industrial city you become used to the foul air and the stench of rotting garbage baking under the hot summer sun. Once the sunlight disappears at the end of this month, today is October 5th. I can only imagine the anxiety that folks living here must feel. With each coming day the sun sits lower and lower in the sky until it is no more. For I have gotten used to getting up in the morning and looking outside and seeing daylight. I'm not sure if I could handle 24 hours of darkness for months on end. I would imagine simple things like traveling around town can have a heightened level of difficulty. Like going to work or grocery shopping for example. Are they delivered? Or do large groups of people band together on snowmobiles and travel to the store? Will I be eaten by a Polar bear? Are there any Starbucks, Walmart's or Ikea's here? Where is the hospital located? Will I walk around talking to myself?

I think this whole "northernmost town" claim is a little out of control, with too many "qualifications."  Svalbard, the northernmost town ... ahem ... with over a 1000 residents (whispered under breath).  Barrow Alaska, the northernmost town ... ahem ... (cough, cough) in the United States.  Alert, in Nunavut, Canada, the northernmost town .... ahem ... if you count a bunch of trailers a town.  Captain Jack's fishing boat ... the northernmost town ... ahem ... when Jack is fishing the Arctic Ocean and his boat happens to be momentarily anchored at the Terrestrial North Pole and if you count a couple of blokes in a fishing boat a town.  Or, is it Captain Buck's fishing boat, that's the "northernmost town" - because if and when it's anchored in the Arctic Ocean, he anchors it at the Magnetic North Pole.  See the problem?

Actually, title is false. The northernmost permanently habited place in the world is Alert, Nunavut, Canada, which is 508 miles from the north pole. It could in theory be considered the part of the north pole at this point.

I shall return next summer without fail.

I had one year during my University degree there, had a course in biotechnology, biochemistry etc., when I arrived in the end of July before the semester start its still midnight sun so its never darker than say 7:30pm where the sun goes down at 8pm The sun is roughly 11° above the horizon. Its in fact not very different going from day to night, so it can be easy to lose all track of time. Then it goes quickly from light all day to become like night time from around mid November to sometime in February. Then its like its midnight the entire day. Super depressing if you have never experienced this before. I miss going out in the winter (Feb-March) with the snowmobile and rifle and just ride in the dusk with no other reason than to explore, take photos eat thermos cooked sausages (yeah not a very fancy meal, but a nice snack to bring along). I saw polar-bears on two occasions, but they were more than 4 and 8 km away, barely saw them with the naked eye, but saw them easily with binoculars! Then sadly / or not, I had to go back to mainland Norway / Oslo 2000 km away!

I experienced something like this in Inuvik, NWT Canada. Water and Sewer lines are all above ground and are heat-traced and insulated to prevent freezing....buildings are constructed on pilings or stilts to prevent ground thawing and foundation shifting....during spring and fall all supplies must be flown in because the surrounding ice roads are not stable enough for trucks and the McKenzie river is too icy for ships (prices rise dramatically)....the few trees are all stunted and misshapen (just a few miles from the circumpolar tree line). A dramatic change in lifestyle for someone used to warmer climates.

I loved it when I went there during the dark period. Waking up in the morning with no idea what time it was, enjoying the faint light of twilight and looking at the absolutely gorgeous northern lights (there really are no words to describe them). I disagree, however, that Svalbard is inhospitable. The climate may be harsh, but Longyearbyen has all the facilities you would look for in a normal city (most of them at least). The people there were also lovely and welcoming. I'd love to go back during the 24-hour day period, although I imagine sleeping might be a bit harder :P .

Hi Derek.

I love the way you piloted that drone. The visuals, the narration and the music were stunning. I suppose the stars in the night sky must be surreal, and the auroras incredible. But I was left with quite a number of unanswered questions that I felt should've been covered. How does such a remote location connect to the rest of the world? Do they have internet access? Cable TV? Cell phone coverage? How do they get fuel for heating their homes, and what kind of fuel? What about water? Is there a sewer system? What do people do for a living in such location? Do they have trains, buses or what kind of mass transportation system? Is there an airport nearby or how far is it? Thanks for sharing.

Anyone can live there. Nationality doesn't matter. As long as they can make a living for themselves. If you're not allowed to live in mainland Norway, you can still live in Svalbard.
Although mainland Norway is part of the Schengen area, Svalbard is not. So even Norwegians have to show their passports when they enter, as they leave the Schengen area.
The islands have lower taxes than mainland Norway.
There are more polar bears on the islands than human beings.
The islands is a demilitarized zone.
Germany, China, France, India, Italy, South-Korea, United Kingdom, Japan and Norway have research bases in Ny-Ålesund.
The town of Barentsburg is inhabited by around 430 people, mostly Russians and Ukrainians. The population have been declining since the Soviet era. Their town crest has a coal miner and two polar bears holding a Russian and a Norwegian flag. Twice a year "athletes" from Longyearbyen meets "athletes" from Barentsburg to compete in football (soccer), badminton, chess, table tennis, floorball, basketball and volleyball (and partying).
Yes, Svalbard is a strange and unique place. Both in terms of climate, research, politics and culture.

I've been there. At summer the first days will have you disoriented. You could end up doing what I did, going to town for an ice cream in this beautiful weather only to realize it's 3 a.m and everyone is asleep. It's surreal how bright and fresh and alive the night looks. The opposite of course goes for the winters, when everything is dark for months on end. Around April, the sun starts coming back and personally I feel like that's the most beautiful part of the year in Svalbard.
When you get there you get there you're struck by a lingering feeling that you're at edge of civilization. Which you are.

Barentzburg, the russian village on Svalbard is also worth visiting if anyone of you decide to go there. It's part of the soviet era and is very much an untouched fossil of soviet life. It's very interesting to see, especially since from every corner of the village you can see the words "Mir o mir" in russian on the mountain just like the Hollywood sign. Mir means both world and peace in russian and "Mir o mir" means world peace. Which stands there as a reminder of the ideals and the dreams of the communists. Gives you an alternate look at the age old enemy of the West.
Production Value = 100/100

Derek, this video is absolutely hypnotic. :)

What struck me most in the footage, was that ridge of pristine icy alabaster mountains, against that constant dusky evening sky. It almost didn't seem real, more like something from an artist's rendition of Hoth... or if Georgia O'Keeffe painted the Arctic Circle instead of the American Southwest. Alien, unforgettable. Add to that, the realization those same x-thousand-foot mountains probably never existed -360Ma, but may be the eroded remains of billions of redwood-sized ferns, sweltering in a Hawaiian climate...

But the drone's intrinsic way of shooting Longyearbyen, was equally mesmerizing -- those slow pans where everything in the shot is in motion, sweeping across juxtapose of the town's past, present, and future. Stunning.

biggest problems you english peeps got when talking norwegian is that you put the pressure all wrong and are in such a hurry.

Longyearbyen is divided into 3 obvious words, long year byen, byen means "the city" so, "The long year city"
Anyway, Byen has pressure on the y (kind of like in byzantine, just without the zantine), this is really the most important thing to pronounce it correctly, other than that you can either pronounce or swallow the e, but you might want to take your time if using the e, or just say "byn"(still with the pressure on the y)

Many communities in the high arctic in northern Canada have a very similar climate and landscape. Sadly, most are not as clean and organized as this and would almost qualify as the 3rd world. Crumbling infrastructure, unreliable power and communications, many buildings abandoned or in a state of disrepair, old vehicles and other junk littering people's yards, lots of people living in overcrowded houses and in poverty, drug and alcohol problems, unemployment. It's really sad to see.

Svalbard is what communities in the Canadian high arctic SHOULD be like.

I'm all for the use of drones to get creative shots. And 4K is cool if you have a compatible monitor. But there is a lack of creativity across the board. It's like everyone with a drone Thinks there are only three shots to be had: 1). Rising over ________ for a reveal. 2). Sweeping panoramic views. 3). Simple linear flyovers. I'd just like to see something different. Remember when that drone flew through a fireworks display? THAT was awesome use of a drone. It was creative. It was exciting. The visuals in this video were nice, but the monotone narration, slow pacing and music made it feel like I was back in school being forced to watch a video while waiting for the bell to ring. I love Veritasium, really... But I prefer the videos that challenge my perception of the world around me, not ones that make me drowsy. And I am not trying to troll this channel. At the end of the day this is Derek's channel and he should totally do it his way. I just miss the old Veritasium where he was teachy, not preachy.

My family lived in Longyearbyen for over a decade, and I lived there a few years as a child myself. I don't have much memory of it, but I visited in 2010 with my parents. They showed me my house (a red house closest to the Advent dale) where we used to live, and the local pub and shops. We took a trip on snowmobiles to a nearby settlement called Barentsburg, 30 minutes away. Barentsburg is a Russian settlement and ghost town that was abounded after the price of coal went down. It was really surreal. My dad was a miner in mine number 7 and my mother a cleaning lady in mine number 3, and they and my older brother and sister spend a huge chunk of their lives there. My mum and dad still comes back every now and then to visit old neighbours and friends. Spitsbergen is one of those places you just can't look at pictures of, you have to see it for yourself. The town is located at the end of a glacier (which you can go under), and the most fun you will ever have is when you rent a snowmobile and drive down the glacier. The nature around the town is the most interesting part of it all.

Fun fact:

Since milk has a short expiration date, it has to be sent by air to the local shop, instead of the cheaper method of boat. This means that a carton of milk is far more expensive than beer in Longyearbyen. Thanks for reading!

I'm getting a romantic vibe from the videography and music, but I can't find anything remotely romantic about this place. To me it represents the worst of humanity, exploiting natural untouched habitats, endangering indigenous animals, wasting oil to create a habitable environment in an unhabitable location in the first place. Yes, the mountains and the snow are majestic and beautiful. But the poluting snowmobiles and mining operations and the polarbear killing inhabitants soil this beautiful pure place. How remote and hostile does nature have to be to be free from human colonisation?

Did you know it's illegal to die on Svalbard? If you get deathly ill you are shipped back to the mainland immediately. It's because of the permafrost. Bodies doesn't rot and then they get pushed up from the ground. They stopped burying people on Svalbard about 70 years ago. You also cannot give birth, I guess because of limited facilities to accomodate these things. And if you're gonna live on Svalbard you gotta pull your own weight and contribute to the community in some way and take care of yourself, you cannot be a burden. So yeah, the environment isn't the only thing that makes living on Svalbard a challenge. If you cannot do that you are put on the first plane back home. Btw, the text below that polar bear warning sign said something along the lines of "goes for all of Svalbard". xD
